title: How to Bowl an Outswinger in Cricket

steps.title: Select a relatively young ball.
steps.content: Select a relatively young ball. Aerodynamics play a crucial role in swing bowls, and the longer a ball has been in use, the more its surface changes over time. Balls that have been in use for 20 years or more tend to effect a “reverse swing,” which means that the technique used to pitch a natural outswinger may result in an inswinger instead. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Choose one side of the ball to polish.
steps.content: Choose one side of the ball to polish. The primary seam of a cricket ball runs along the ball’s center, creating two halves. Polishing one half will decrease air resistance on that side, causing the ball to swing in the direction of its other, rougher side when thrown. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Apply spit or sweat to the polished side.
steps.content: Apply spit or sweat to the polished side. Rub it in with your trousers. Repeat frequently throughout the game, in between each delivery. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Inform your teammates as to which side is which to ensure consistency.
steps.content: Inform your teammates as to which side is which to ensure consistency. Encourage them to shine the ball further while it’s in their possession during the match. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Angle the seam toward the slips.
steps.content: Angle the seam toward the slips. Rather than keeping the primary seam vertical, it should be angled slightly away from the batter.

steps.title: Hold the ball with the polished side facing the batsman, or their “leg side.”
steps.content: Hold the ball with the polished side facing the batsman, or their “leg side.” The aim of the out swing is to force the batsman to strike the ball away from his body, on his “off side.” Since the ball will swing in the direction of its rough side, grip the ball with the rough half facing the batsman’s off side. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Grip the ball with your thumb along the seam on the bottom.
steps.content: Grip the ball with your thumb along the seam on the bottom. Spread your index and middle fingers slightly apart from each other along the seam on top. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Aim the seam at your first or second slip fielder.
steps.content: Aim the seam at your first or second slip fielder. [7] X Research source The ball will swing wherever you aim the seam, so angling the seam away from the batsman, at a 15-20º toward the slips, will send the ball towards them instead of directly at the batsman. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Allow plenty of distance for your run-up.
steps.content: Allow plenty of distance for your run-up. More distance will allow you to build momentum for a powerful delivery.

steps.title: Face your target.
steps.content: Face your target. Your body’s momentum will instinctively follow the direction in which your head is aimed. Hold your head steady with your eyes fixed on your target. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Balance your run.
steps.content: Balance your run. Speed alone can deliver a powerful bowl, but a steady rhythm helps, too. Keep your speed consistent and your motions fluid, balanced, and relaxed. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Increase your strides as you near the batsman.
steps.content: Increase your strides as you near the batsman. [11] X Research source Run straight in like an athlete as you approach the stump. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Bowl close to the stump.
steps.content: Bowl close to the stump. [13] X Research source Once bowled, the ball should ideally begin to swing late in its delivery. Decrease the distance between yourself and the batsman before you bowl to ensure that the ball doesn’t swing too soon.

steps.title: Tempt the batsman to play the ball.
steps.content: Tempt the batsman to play the ball. Aim at either the stump itself or very close to it. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Focus on your front arm.
steps.content: Focus on your front arm. Keep it high at first. Then, as you bowl, pull it straight down, close to your body. This will keep the front of your body clear for your bowling arm to follow through after the ball’s release.

steps.title: Release the ball.
steps.content: Release the ball. Pitch it while your bowling arm is still high. When you release the ball, angle your wrist down and across the ball toward the slips. Follow through by bringing your bowling arm down across your body so that your fingers touch your other armpit.
